title: Tropical Modern Miami Beach Adobe Hits Market for $23.5M
text:
A tropical modernist house on Palm Island, Florida, is on the market for $23.5 million.

Text size

A modern waterfront abode in Miami Beach, Florida, will come onto the market for $23.5 million, Mansion Global has learned.

The house was owned by Dean Carr, 41, an investor originally from London, and his wife, Melissa, 36, who is from Rhode Island.

The two met in Miami years ago. In 2013, they celebrated their wedding there with a performance by Grammy-award winning musician Lionel Richie. Then they decided to build their dream home on the beach.

“We felt close to Miami and imagined building our dream home and raising our children forever in it,” Mr. Carr said.

He and Ms. Carr purchased an approximately 0.4-acre property on Palm Island for $6.5 million in September 2014. They commissioned famed local architect Choeff Levy Fischman to build a tropical modernist home, which typically combines the clean lines and muted color palette of contemporary design with exotic woods and stone.

The two-story, 9,600-square-foot residence was completed in 2018.

“We watched the house grow from the ground up to the beautiful home it became,” Mrs. Carr said. “We were most proud of our high-end finishes and the beautiful atrium.”

The open-air atrium is a focal point of the residence. It spans 460 square feet with floating steps that lead to a shallow pool of water.

Water features are spread out throughout the property, though. The private driveway boasts a colossal water cascade, there are reflecting ponds and an infinity-edge pool around the sides of the residence, which itself sits on 110-foot water frontage.

High-end finishes include its gray limestone exteriors, a floor-to-ceiling gas fireplace with bespoke brass paneling, a central $500,000 gourmet kitchen by Fendi with chocolate lacquer floor-to-ceiling cabinetry and champagne leather paneling, and an Ipe wood staircase with a unique Italian tile wall, among other things.

The house has 9,600 square feet of living space. LPG/Douglas Elliman

The house has six bedrooms, seven-and-a-half bathrooms, and an open-concept living room with 12-foot ceilings and floor-to-ceiling sliding glass doors that open up to the rear deck.

The master bedroom suite on the second floor has 1,490 square feet of livable space, overlooking Biscayne Bay on one side and the glass atrium on the opposite end. It includes a lounge, a fireplace, and two spacious bathrooms featuring exotic floor-to-ceiling marble and a seamless glass zero-edge spa shower.

“Our favorite space was our outdoor living space that we really enjoyed with family and friends, and our movie theater where we actually spent more family time,” Mrs. Carr said.

Additional amenities include a fully integrated Savant home automation technology system, one of the largest residential-grade elevators, serving three levels, a private rooftop and a motor court with a British-made automobile rotating turntable.

“The rotating turntable, one of the only two in Miami Beach, is inspired by houses in the South of France,” said Dina Goldentayer of Douglas Elliman, who is listing the property Wednesday.

Palm Island is a prestigious, gated residential community five minutes from both South Beach and downtown Miami, Ms. Goldentayer said.

The Carrs decided to sell the house because they’ve moved to Monaco, where they wanted to raise their two young children, Mrs. Carr said.

This article originally appeared on Mansion Global.
